snippet: As fighters with ISIS bore down Tuesday on the Turkish border, President Obama’s plan to fight the militant group without being drawn deeper into the Syrian civil war was coming under acute strain.
abstract: Pres Obama's plan to fight Islamic State group without being drawn deeper into Syrian civil war comes under acute strain as militant fighters bear down on Syrian town of Kobani on Turkish border; Turkish Pres Recep Tayyip Erdogan says country will not get more deeply involved in conflict unless United States agrees to give great support to Syrian rebels.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER, ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Mark Landler and Eric Schmitt reported from Washington, and Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon. Reporting was contributed by Karam Shoumali from Mursitpinar, Turkey; Somini Sengupta from the United Nations; Sebnem Arsu from Istanbul; and Alan Cowell from London.

lead_paragraph: As fighters with ISIS bore down Tuesday on the Turkish border, President Obama’s plan to fight the militant group without being drawn deeper into the Syrian civil war was coming under acute strain.

headline.main: Turkish Inaction on ISIS Advance Dismays the U.S.
headline.print_headline: Turkish Inaction on ISIS Advance Dismays the U.S.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
